resource.chars:
my own observations. The positions of the defective colour, 
of white, and of yellow as deduced from Mr Simpsons equations 
alone, are given at "d" "w" and "y". The positions of these 
points, as deduced from a combination of these equations 
with my own are given at "D", "W" and "Y". The difference 
of these positions from those of "d" "w" and "y" shows the 
amount of discrepancy between observation and theory. 

It will be observed that D is situated near V (vermillion), 
but that a line from D to W cuts UV at C near to V. D is therefore 
a red colour, not scarlet, but further from yellow 
It may be called crimson, and may be <u>imitated<\u>  by a mixture 
of 86 vermillion and 14 ultramarine This compound colour 
will be of the same <u>hue<\u> as D but since <s>D<\s> c lies between 
D and W, c must be regarded as D diluted with a certain 
amount of white, and therefore D must be imagined to be 
like c in hue, but without the intermixture of white 
which is unavoidable in actual pigments and which 
reduces the purity of the tint. 

Lines drawn from D through "W" and "Y", <s>pass through<\s> 
the colourblind positions of white & yellow pass through 
W & Y, their positions in ordinary vision. The reason 
why they do not coincide with W & Y is that the white and 
yellow papers are much brighter than the colours corresponding 
to the points W & Y of the triangle V,U,G <s>since<\s> and therefore 
lines from D, which represent them in intensity as well 
as <s>[text?]<\s> in quality, must be longer than DW & DY in <s>that<\s> the 
proportion of their brightness
